yes_case.guidance: Refer to IAS 8 for changes in accounting policies, corrections of errors, and recognition requirements under IFRS standards. Analyze the justification provided by the entity and ensure it aligns with IFRS guidelines.

items.question: Are the financial statements authorised for issue according to the entity's governing process?
items.original_question: Does the entity disclose the date when the financial statements were authorised for issue?

decision_tree.question: Are the financial statements authorised for issue according to the entity's governing process?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the entity's documentation to confirm whether the financial statements have been finalised and authorised for issue by the appropriate authority (e.g., board of directors, management). This date should be traceable in board minutes or equivalent records. Ensure the process aligns with applicable governance requirements.

yes_case.question: Does the entity disclose the date when the financial statements were authorised for issue?
yes_case.guidance: Review the notes or footnotes of the financial statements. Typically, the disclosure appears in the general information section or notes section. Ensure the date is clearly stated and matches the authorisation documentation.

items.question: Have the financial statements been prepared by the entity for the reporting period?
items.original_question: Does the entity disclose who authorised the financial statements?

decision_tree.question: Have the financial statements been prepared by the entity for the reporting period?
decision_tree.guidance: Verify the existence of audited financial statements for the reporting period. Check the covering page or the introductory section for confirmation of the reporting period.

yes_case.question: Does the entity's financial statements include information on who authorised them for issue?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the notes or the final statement section of the financial report. Look for explicit mention of the authorisation for issue, including the name or designation of the individual or governing body responsible. IAS 10.17 requires disclosure of this information to identify the date and authority under which the statements were authorised.

yes_case.question: Is the authorisation disclosure compliant with IAS 10.17 requirements, including necessary details such as authorisation date and identity of the responsible party?
yes_case.guidance: Verify that the disclosure includes the exact date of authorisation and clear identification of the individual(s) or governing body responsible. Ensure there is no ambiguity and details align with IAS 10 guidance. Cross-check against minutes of meetings or resolutions if needed.

items.question: Do owners or others have the power to amend the financial statements after they have been issued?
items.original_question: Does the entity disclose that owners or others have the power to amend the financial statements after issue, if applicable?

decision_tree.question: Do owners or others have the power to amend the financial statements after they have been issued?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the entity's governance arrangements and legal framework for the reporting period. Specific documentation to review includes the entity's articles of incorporation, bylaws, shareholder agreements, and relevant laws/regulations governing financial reporting amendments. Ensure you verify the entity's disclosures regarding this power, if applicable.

yes_case.question: Has the entity disclosed in the financial statements that owners or others have the power to amend the financial statements after issue?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the notes to the financial statements for explicit disclosure regarding the ability of owners or others to amend issued financial statements. Focus on areas related to subsequent events and governance disclosures. Ensure the disclosure is complete and clear, as per IAS 10.17.

sections.title: Financial review by management
sections.description: Checklist for presentation and disclosure requirements under IFRS 18.

items.question: Does the entity prepare management reports or similar documentation separate from the financial statements to review financial performance, financial position, and principal uncertainties?
items.original_question: Does the entity provide information for financial review by management, which is separate from the financial statements, that describes and explains the main features of its financial performance and financial position and the principal uncertainties it faces

decision_tree.question: Does the entity prepare management reports or similar documentation separate from the financial statements to review financial performance, financial position, and principal uncertainties?
decision_tree.guidance: Check whether the entity produces internal or external reports designed for management review of financial performance. These may include management commentaries, business reviews, or similar narrative reports that describe and explain the business context. Examine company policies, meeting minutes, or designated management reporting templates.

yes_case.question: Do these reports provide sufficient information describing the main features of financial performance and financial position?
yes_case.guidance: Ensure the report contains detailed, accurate, and relevant information about the entity's revenues, expenses, cash flows, and financial health. Verify that the information is not overly summarized and provides explanations of significant movements or trends.

yes_case.question: Do the reports describe the principal uncertainties faced by the entity?
yes_case.guidance: Check for discussion or disclosure of risks, external market uncertainties, regulatory changes, or other significant factors impacting the entity. Review risk sections or forward-looking statements in the report if applicable.

sections.title: Aggregation and disaggregation
sections.description: Checklist for presentation and disclosure requirements under IFRS 18.

items.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in accordance with IFRS standards?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify and aggregate assets, liabilities, equity, income, expenses or cash flows into items based on shared characteristics, unless doing so would override specific aggregation or disaggregation requirements in IFRS?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in accordance with IFRS standards?
decision_tree.guidance: Verify if the entity has stated in its financial statements that it complies with IFRS standards. Look for this statement in the basis of preparation note within the financial statements. If this statement is missing, the checklist item will be 'Not Applicable'.

yes_case.question: Has the entity classified and aggregated assets, liabilities, equity, income, expenses, or cash flows into items based on shared characteristics?
yes_case.guidance: Review the financial statements and disclosures. Check for groupings and classifications within the Statement of Financial Position, Statement of Comprehensive Income, and Statement of Cash Flows. Aggregation should be based on shared characteristics such as nature, function, or liquidity. Common pitfalls include inappropriate grouping or failure to provide additional disaggregation when required.

yes_case.question: Does the classification or aggregation override specific aggregation or disaggregation requirements provided in IFRS standards?
yes_case.guidance: Compare the entity's classifications and aggregations against the requirements of IFRS 18.41 and IFRS 18.B16-B23. Pay special attention to standards that mandate disaggregation, such as separate disclosures for significant classes of assets, liabilities, or income items. Disregarding these requirements constitutes non-compliance.

items.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements that include any items requiring disaggregation under IFRS 18?
items.original_question: Does the entity disaggregate items based on characteristics that are not shared, unless doing so would override specific aggregation or disaggregation requirements in IFRS?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements that include any items requiring disaggregation under IFRS 18?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the financial statements and identify items that involve combining several components or transactions. Check IFRS 18.41 and IFRS 18.B16-B23 for examples of items that may need disaggregation based on differences in characteristics.

yes_case.question: Are the shared characteristics of items being aggregated consistent with the requirements of IFRS 18?
yes_case.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.41 and IFRS 18.B16-B23 for guidance on shared characteristics that justify aggregation (e.g., if items are of a sufficiently similar nature or function). Document any judgment applied in determining shared characteristics, and verify with supporting schedules or disclosures.

yes_case.question: Does the entity avoid overriding specific aggregation or disaggregation requirements stated in IFRS 18?
yes_case.guidance: Ensure that no aggregation or disaggregation decisions violate explicit requirements in IFRS 18 (e.g., specific guidelines about presenting customer contracts or performance obligations per IFRS 18). Cross-check specific requirements within IFRS 18.B16-B23.

items.question: Do the primary financial statements include line items that could be subject to aggregation or disaggregation to provide useful structured summaries?
items.original_question: Does the entity aggregate or disaggregate items to present line items in the primary financial statements that fulfil their role of providing useful structured summaries, unless doing so would override specific IFRS requirements?

decision_tree.question: Do the primary financial statements include line items that could be subject to aggregation or disaggregation to provide useful structured summaries?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the primary financial statements, including the Statement of Financial Position, Statement of Profit or Loss, and Statement of Cash Flows. Look for items that may require further breakdown or consolidation based on their materiality and the nature of the transactions they represent. Ensure completeness by reviewing IFRS 18.41 and B16-B23 for specific aggregation and disaggregation guidance.

yes_case.question: Has the entity aggregated or disaggregated line items in a manner that provides structured summaries while remaining compliant with IFRS 18?
yes_case.guidance: Evaluate whether line item aggregation or disaggregation improves the clarity and usefulness of the financial information. Cross-reference this with IFRS 18.41 and examples provided in IFRS 18.B16-B23 to ensure compliance with requirements. Common pitfalls include over-aggregation, making line items too generic, or disaggregation that introduces excessive or confusing detail.

items.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in accordance with IFRS standards?
items.original_question: Does the entity aggregate or disaggregate items to disclose information in the notes that fulfils their role of providing material information, unless doing so would override specific IFRS requirements?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in accordance with IFRS standards?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the accounting policies section and compliance statements in the financial statements. Confirm whether the entity explicitly states compliance with IFRS Standards, including IFRS 18. Check for any departures, such as using local GAAP.

yes_case.question: Has the entity provided any notes to the financial statements that aggregate or disaggregate information?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the notes to the financial statements, particularly those related to disclosures under IFRS 18. Look for grouping (aggregation) or separation (disaggregation) of information. Check sections IFRS 18.41 and IFRS 18.B16-B23 for detailed guidance on these practices.

yes_case.question: Does the aggregation or disaggregation of items ensure material information is clearly and suitably disclosed?
yes_case.guidance: Assess the relevance and materiality of the information disclosed. Aggregation should combine items with similar nature/function, while disaggregation should separate items where such separation provides better understanding. Be particularly vigilant about overriding specific IFRS requirements; check references IFRS 18.41 and IFRS 18.B16-B23.

items.question: Does the entity present aggregated or disaggregated information in its financial statements?
items.original_question: Does the entity ensure that its aggregation and disaggregation do not obscure material information, unless doing so would override specific IFRS requirements?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity present aggregated or disaggregated information in its financial statements?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the financial statements, focusing on how information is presented. Aggregated information may combine several items or transactions into a single figure, while disaggregated information breaks them down into components. Consult IFRS 18.41 for guidance on appropriate aggregation.

yes_case.question: Do aggregation or disaggregation methods obscure material information?
yes_case.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.41 and IFRS 18.B16-B23 to determine if the presentation obscures material information. Materiality is judged based on the size, nature, and context of items. Look for cases where aggregation or disaggregation may impair users' ability to understand the financial statements.

yes_case.question: Does the method of aggregation or disaggregation comply with specific IFRS requirements?
yes_case.guidance: Check whether the entity overrides any specific IFRS standards (e.g., mandatory disclosures). IFRS 18.B16-B23 provides clarity on when overriding may be necessary or impermissible.

items.question: Does the entity apply IFRS 18 for revenue recognition?
items.original_question: Does the entity disaggregate items under IFRS 18.41 whenever the resulting information is material?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity apply IFRS 18 for revenue recognition?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the entity's business model and financial statements to determine if revenues are recognized under IFRS 18. Refer to the Statement of Profit or Loss and Note disclosures for revenue accounting policies.

yes_case.question: Are there items recognized under IFRS 18.41 that could be disaggregated to provide material information?
yes_case.guidance: Review the revenue line items and supporting note disclosures. IFRS 18.41 mentions that revenue should be presented by categories such as type, geographical area, or timing of transfer of goods/services. Determine if these categories could contain material information.

yes_case.question: Has the entity disaggregated the items in compliance with IFRS 18.42 when the resulting information is material?
yes_case.guidance: Verify disclosures, typically in the notes to the financial statements. Ensure disaggregation provides meaningful insights into revenue streams. Common pitfalls include insufficient detail or overly aggregated figures violating the standard.

items.question: Has the entity applied IFRS 18.41(c) while preparing its financial statements?
items.original_question: If, applying IFRS 18.41(c), the entity does not present material information in the primary financial statements, does it disclose that information in the notes?

decision_tree.question: Has the entity applied IFRS 18.41(c) while preparing its financial statements?
decision_tree.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.41(c) in the accounting policies section. This is typically applied when material information is relevant but not presented in the primary financial statements. Ensure the entity's policies comply with the principles of IFRS 18. Review the primary financial statements to determine whether IFRS 18.41(c) is applicable in practice.

yes_case.question: Has the entity presented all material information in the primary financial statements as required?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the primary financial statements (e.g., Statement of Financial Position, Statement of Comprehensive Income). Material information must be explicitly stated and not omitted. Cross-check with IFRS 18.42 and IFRS 18.B79 to understand what qualifies as 'material information' under IFRS guidelines.

no_case.question: Has the entity disclosed material information omitted from the primary financial statements in the notes?
no_case.guidance: Review the notes to the financial statements for any disclosures that complement the primary financial statements. Per IFRS 18.B111, ensure that omitted material information is appropriately disclosed here to ensure users of financial statements have all necessary data.

items.question: Has the entity prepared primary financial statements or notes according to IFRS?
items.original_question: Does the entity label and describe items presented in the primary financial statements or in the notes in a way that faithfully represents the characteristics of each item?

decision_tree.question: Has the entity prepared primary financial statements or notes according to IFRS?
decision_tree.guidance: Verify whether the entity has prepared financial statements (including Statement of Financial Position, Statement of Profit or Loss, Statement of Cash Flows, and accompanying notes) in compliance with IFRS. Refer to the entity's financial reporting framework and confirm IFRS is applied. Common pitfalls include mislabeling financial statements or using a different accounting framework.

yes_case.question: Are the items presented in the primary financial statements or notes appropriately labeled and described to faithfully represent their characteristics?
yes_case.guidance: Review the labeling and descriptions used in the financial statements and notes. Pay specific attention to whether the labels (e.g., 'Trade Receivables', 'Revenue', 'Cost of Sales') and descriptions accurately reflect the economic substance, nature, and characteristics of each item. Cross-check with the definitions in IFRS 18. Common issues include vague descriptions or misleading titles.

items.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in accordance with IFRS standards?
items.original_question: To faithfully represent an item, does the entity provide all descriptions and explanations necessary for users to understand that item?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in accordance with IFRS standards?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the entity's accounting policies and disclosures in the financial statements to ensure compliance with IFRS standards. Verify if the entity explicitly states that it prepares its financial statements in accordance with IFRS.

yes_case.question: Does the entity provide all descriptions and explanations necessary for users to understand each item in the financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Review the financial statements for sufficient disclosures and explanations. Inspect specific sections such as notes to financial statements, accounting policy disclosures, and the presentation of line items. Ensure descriptions are complete and appropriately labeled. Common pitfalls include missing or generic explanations that lead to user confusion.

no_case.question: Are the omissions or insufficient explanations significant enough to potentially mislead users or obscure understanding of the financial statements?
no_case.guidance: Evaluate the materiality of omitted information. Refer to IAS 1.31 and IAS 1.122 requiring material items to be disclosed and described sufficiently. Consider whether the missing details impair users' ability to make economic decisions.

items.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in compliance with IFRS standards?
items.original_question: Does the entity separately report assets and liabilities, and income and expenses, unless offsetting is required or permitted by an IFRS accounting standard?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity prepare financial statements in compliance with IFRS standards?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's financial statements and verify if they explicitly state compliance with IFRS. Look for a note or statement in the accounting policies section confirming adherence to IFRS.

yes_case.question: Does the entity offset assets and liabilities or income and expenses in the financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the Statement of Financial Position and Statement of Profit or Loss and Other Comprehensive Income. Specifically, check whether any assets and liabilities, or income and expenses, are reported as net amounts instead of separate line items.

yes_case.question: Is the offsetting permitted or required by an IFRS accounting standard?
yes_case.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.44-45 and other relevant IFRS standards to determine if the offsetting complies with IFRS guidance. Common issues include offsetting unrelated items or failing to meet specific IFRS criteria for offsetting (e.g., legal enforceability or contractual rights).

sections.title: Statement of profit or loss
sections.description: Checklist for presentation and disclosure requirements under IFRS 18.

items.question: Does the entity recognize revenue under IFRS 18?
items.original_question: Does the entity disaggregate items under IFRS 18.41 whenever the resulting information is material?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity recognize revenue under IFRS 18?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the financial statements and accounting policies note to confirm if the entity recognizes revenue under IFRS 18. Refer to contracts with customers and check if revenue arises from the entity's ordinary activities. Make sure the standard explicitly applies to the entity's transactions.

yes_case.question: Are there multiple distinct items or categories of revenue that could be disaggregated based on their character or customer type?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the revenue disclosures in the notes to the financial statements. Look for distinct classes of revenue streams, such as product sales, service revenue, or geographic factors. Ensure disaggregation matches IFRS 18.41 requirements.

yes_case.question: Is the disaggregated information material to understanding the entity's financial results?
yes_case.guidance: Evaluate whether disaggregation enhances the user’s understanding of the financial statements. Assess quantitative and qualitative aspects of materiality. Refer to IFRS Practice Statement on Materiality.

yes_case.question: Has the entity correctly disaggregated revenue whenever it is material?
yes_case.guidance: Check if the required disaggregation is clearly presented in the notes to the financial statements. Ensure all material categories are disclosed with clear explanations. Compare disclosures against IFRS 18.41 guidance.

items.question: Does the entity apply IFRS 18.41(c)?
items.original_question: If, applying IFRS 18.41(c), the entity does not present material information in the primary financial statements, does it disclose that information in the notes?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity apply IFRS 18.41(c)?
decision_tree.guidance: Check if the entity's revenue recognition involves the criteria outlined in IFRS 18.41(c), which relates to situations where material information is not presented in the primary financial statements. Review the relevant sections of the revenue recognition policies and financial statements to confirm applicability.

yes_case.question: Has the entity omitted material information from the primary financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Identify any missing material information by comparing the primary financial statements against IFRS 18 disclosure requirements and entity-specific significant accounting policies. Common pitfalls include underestimating transaction significance or aggregation of details that obscure transparency.

yes_case.question: Does the entity disclose the omitted material information appropriately in the notes to the financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Review the notes section to confirm that all omitted material information is disclosed and adheres to the requirements of IFRS 18.B79 and IFRS 18.B111. Ensure the disclosures provide sufficient clarity and are not obscured by excessive aggregation.

items.question: Does the entity prepare a statement of profit or loss for the reporting period?
items.original_question: Does the entity include all items of income and expense in a reporting period in the statement of profit or loss, unless an IFRS accounting standard requires or permits otherwise?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity prepare a statement of profit or loss for the reporting period?
decision_tree.guidance: Verify whether the entity has prepared a statement of profit or loss as part of its financial statements for the reporting period. Review the financial statements and confirm the existence of this statement, as per IAS 1 Presentation of Financial Statements.

yes_case.question: Does the entity include all items of income and expense in the statement of profit or loss, except where another IFRS standard requires or permits otherwise?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the statement of profit or loss and cross-reference it with other applicable IFRS standards that might require or permit certain items to be excluded. Pay special attention to items that could be classified under other comprehensive income or presented due to specific IFRS policies (e.g., IFRS 9, IFRS 16).

yes_case.question: Are any exclusions justified by an IFRS accounting standard?
yes_case.guidance: Review the exclusions provided by the entity and match them to allowable exceptions explicitly mentioned in IFRS standards. Check the reasoning supplied in the notes to the financial statements for compliance with the applicable standards.

items.question: Does the entity invest in assets as a main business activity?
items.original_question: If the entity invests in assets as a main business activity, does the entity disclose that fact?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity invest in assets as a main business activity?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's business description and financial statements, focusing on the Notes to the Financial Statements and Management Reporting disclosures. Consider the entity's operational strategy and look for indications in annual reports or investor communications about asset investments being a primary focus. Common pitfalls include misidentifying incidental investments or failing to differentiate between primary and secondary business activities.

yes_case.question: Does the entity disclose that investing in assets is a main business activity?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the Notes to the Financial Statements under the 'Nature of Business' section or similar disclosures. The entity should include explicit mentions of investing in assets as a principal activity in clearly identifiable sections. Ensure this is explicitly stated and not implied.

items.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers as a main business activity?
items.original_question: If the entity provides financing to customers as a main business activity, does the entity disclose that fact?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers as a main business activity?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's financial statements and business description documents, such as the 'Notes to the Accounts' or the 'Management Discussion and Analysis' section. Check whether providing financing is explicitly mentioned as a core part of the entity’s operations. Common pitfalls: Do not confuse incidental financing (e.g., installment plans) with financing as a main business activity.

yes_case.question: Has the entity disclosed that fact in its financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Inspect the 'Notes to the Accounts' section of the financial statements. Look for a specific disclosure stating that financing customers is a main business activity. Ensure this disclosure stands out clearly and is not implied or incomplete.

items.question: Has there been a change in the outcome of the assessment under IFRS 18?
items.original_question: If the outcome of the assessment has changed, does the entity disclose that fact and the date of the change?

decision_tree.question: Has there been a change in the outcome of the assessment under IFRS 18?
decision_tree.guidance: Review entity's contracts and assessments under IFRS 18 to determine if there was any updated judgment or change in the outcome. Pay close attention to amendments or revisions to terms, expectations, or conditions. Consult documentation related to significant judgments to confirm.

yes_case.question: Has the entity disclosed the fact of the change and the date of the change in its financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Verify that the financial statements specifically mention the change in the outcome of the assessment and include the date it occurred. Check the notes to the financial statements, particularly under areas discussing revenue recognition or contract modifications.

items.question: Has the entity experienced a change in the outcome of an assessment related to items of income and expense in the current reporting period?
items.original_question: Does the entity disclose the amount and classification of items of income and expense before and after the date of the change in the outcome of the assessment in the current period?

decision_tree.question: Has the entity experienced a change in the outcome of an assessment related to items of income and expense in the current reporting period?
decision_tree.guidance: Review documentation related to the assessments of income and expense items during the reporting period, including any recalculations, management decisions, or external factors affecting these assessments. Refer to financial statements, accounting memos, or other supporting documents that detail changes. Common pitfalls include overlooking minor adjustments or relying solely on initial assessments without accounting for updates.

yes_case.question: Has the entity disclosed the amount and classification of the items of income and expense before the date of the change and after the date of the change?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the notes to the financial statements, specifically disclosures surrounding changes in assessed items. Verify that amounts and classifications for periods before and after the change are documented clearly. Ensure that all relevant changes are traceable to the supporting calculations or records. Warning: Do not assume compliance based on generic or incomplete disclosure.

items.question: Did the entity change the classification of items due to the changed outcome of an assessment?
items.original_question: Does the entity disclose the amount and classification in the prior period for items whose classification changed because of the changed outcome of the assessment?

decision_tree.question: Did the entity change the classification of items due to the changed outcome of an assessment?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the financial statements and notes for disclosures about reclassification of items. Look for sections discussing changes arising from new assessments, such as changes to accounting estimates or outcomes that affect item classification.

yes_case.question: Did the entity disclose the amount and classification of the reclassified items for the prior period?
yes_case.guidance: Review the notes to the financial statements for disclosures explaining the prior period figures. Ensure that both the amounts and classifications of reclassified items are clearly stated. Check the alignment with IFRS 18.51(c) requirements to report prior period comparatives.

items.question: Is the entity required to disclose the information specified in IFRS 18.51(c)?
items.original_question: If the entity does not disclose the information specified in (c) above because it is impracticable, does it disclose that fact?

decision_tree.question: Is the entity required to disclose the information specified in IFRS 18.51(c)?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the requirements in IFRS 18.51(c), which typically pertain to specific disclosures regarding revenue recognition. Check whether the entity's transactions fall under the scope of these requirements. Use supporting contracts, agreements, and transaction details to make this assessment.

yes_case.question: Has the entity disclosed the required information specified in IFRS 18.51(c)?
yes_case.guidance: Verify the disclosures in the financial statements. Look for explicit mention of the required details under Section IFRS 18.51(c). Ensure completeness and accuracy, including the inclusion of all required categories.

no_case.question: Is it impracticable for the entity to disclose the required information?
no_case.guidance: Evaluate whether the entity has documented and justified the impracticality of disclosing the information. This could include limitations such as a lack of data, excessive cost, or unavailability of relevant information. Verify supporting evidence for the claim.

yes_case.question: Has the entity disclosed the fact that it is impracticable to provide the required information?
yes_case.guidance: Check the notes to the financial statements for a statement explicitly mentioning that the disclosure was not possible and the reasons for impracticality. This statement should reflect transparency and adherence to IFRS 18.51(c).

items.question: Has the entity made a change to the outcome of an assessment related to the classification of income and expenses under IFRS 18?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify and present income and expenses applying the change in outcome of the assessment prospectively from the date of the change and not reclassify amounts presented before that date?

decision_tree.question: Has the entity made a change to the outcome of an assessment related to the classification of income and expenses under IFRS 18?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the financial statements and accounting records. Look for changes made to classifications of income and expenses during the reporting period. Examine documentation describing retrospective adjustments or prospectively applied changes. Cross-check with any related disclosures or accounting policies.

yes_case.question: Has the entity applied the change prospectively from the date of the change and avoided reclassifying amounts presented before the change?
yes_case.guidance: Inspect the timing and methodology of the change recorded in the financial statements. Verify that amounts classified prior to the change have not been adjusted or restated retroactively. Pay attention to Notes in the financial statements explaining the nature of the change.

items.question: Does the statement of profit or loss contain income or expenses not classified within investing, financing, income taxes, or discontinued operations categories?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify in the operating category all income and expenses included in the statement of profit or loss that are not classified in the investing, financing, income taxes, or discontinued operations categories?

decision_tree.question: Does the statement of profit or loss contain income or expenses not classified within investing, financing, income taxes, or discontinued operations categories?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the statement of profit or loss in the financial statements. Check whether there are any income or expense items that do not fall under the specified categories of investing, financing, income taxes, or discontinued operations. Carefully refer to IFRS 18.52 for category definitions and common examples. Ensure no misclassification due to misunderstanding definitions.

yes_case.question: Are all such income and expense items correctly classified under the operating category?
yes_case.guidance: Inspect the classification of income and expense items that are not investing, financing, income taxes, or discontinued operations. Ensure they are reported within the operating category as indicated by IFRS 18.52. Verify line items for correct categorization and cross-reference classification policies in the financial disclosure.

items.question: Does the entity have investments in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify income and expenses related to investments in associates, joint ventures and unconsolidated subsidiaries in the investing category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have investments in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the financial statements, specifically the Statement of Financial Position and related notes. Look for line items or disclosures that indicate the existence of investments in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries. Common pitfalls: Ensure the investments meet the definitions in IFRS 18 and that they are not consolidated subsidiaries.

yes_case.question: Does the entity generate income and expenses from these investments?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the Statement of Profit or Loss and associated notes. Identify whether there are income and expense items related to the investments, such as share of profit/loss from associates, dividends, or impairment charges.

yes_case.question: Are these income and expense items classified in the investing category of the Statement of Cash Flows?
yes_case.guidance: Verify the classification of cash flows in the investing activities section of the Statement of Cash Flows. According to IFRS 18.53, income and expenses related to investments in associates, joint ventures, and unconsolidated subsidiaries should be classified within investing activities. Check for proper categorization and ensure compliance with IFRS disclosure objectives.

items.question: Does the entity report income or expenses related to cash and cash equivalents in its financial statements?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify income and expenses related to cash and cash equivalents in the investing category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity report income or expenses related to cash and cash equivalents in its financial statements?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the Statement of Profit or Loss and other relevant notes. Look for reported income (e.g., interest income) or expenses (e.g., bank charges) specifically attributed to cash and cash equivalents. Ensure you identify these items accurately from proper documentation, avoiding misclassification with other financial assets or liabilities.

yes_case.question: Are the reported income and expenses related to cash and cash equivalents classified under the investing activities category in the Statement of Cash Flows?
yes_case.guidance: Check the Statement of Cash Flows and verify where these income and expense items are classified. Confirm that these items are categorized under 'investing activities' as required by IFRS 18.53. Ensure consistent classification in accordance with the definitions provided in the standard. A common pitfall is inadvertently classifying these under operating activities.

items.question: Does the entity have assets that generate income and expenses individually and largely independently of its other resources?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify income and expenses related to other assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of its other resources in the investing category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have assets that generate income and expenses individually and largely independently of its other resources?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's asset register or financial statement notes to identify assets such as investments or other resources earning returns independently. Common examples include held-to-maturity investments, equity instruments, or rental properties. Ensure assets generating returns independently of core operations are classified separately in relevant documentation.

yes_case.question: Are income and expenses related to these assets classified as part of the investing category in the Statement of Cash Flows?
yes_case.guidance: Check the Statement of Cash Flows under 'Investing Activities'. Income (e.g., interest, dividends) and expenses (e.g., acquisition or disposal costs) should be properly allocated to investing activities if they relate to independently performing assets. Check alignment of classification with IAS 7 guidance.

items.question: Does the entity invest in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries?
items.original_question: If the entity invests in associates, joint ventures and unconsolidated subsidiaries and accounts for them using the equity method, does it classify related income and expenses in the investing category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity invest in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's financial statements and disclosures (e.g., notes to the financial statements under IFRS 12 Disclosure of Interests in Other Entities). Look for investments in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries. Check the entity's balance sheet for any line items indicating investments classified as such.

yes_case.question: Does the entity account for these investments using the equity method?
yes_case.guidance: Verify the accounting policy notes and related disclosures, specifically referencing IFRS 28 Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures. Ensure that the financial statements confirm the use of the equity method (e.g., recognizing the entity's share of profit or loss and other comprehensive income).

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify related income and expenses from these investments in the investing category in the statement of cash flows?
yes_case.guidance: Review the Statement of Cash Flows and confirm that income and expenses related to investments accounted for under the equity method are presented under the investing activities section, as per IFRS 18. Ensure compliance by tracing how income and expenses flow from the equity method investments to this section.

items.question: Does the entity invest in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries?
items.original_question: If the entity invests in associates, joint ventures and unconsolidated subsidiaries and does not account for them using the equity method, does it classify related income and expenses in the operating category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity invest in associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the entity's investments disclosed in the financial statements. Refer to the balance sheet and accompanying notes for details on investments classified as associates, joint ventures, or unconsolidated subsidiaries.

yes_case.question: Does the entity account for these investments using the equity method?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the accounting policy note in the financial statements. The equity method is typically applied under IAS 28 for investments where significant influence exists but no control. Look for explicit references to the equity method.

no_case.question: Does the entity classify income and expenses related to these investments in the operating category?
no_case.guidance: Review the Statement of Profit or Loss and accompanying notes. Ensure related income (e.g., dividends) and expenses (e.g., impairment losses) are classified under operating activities. Cross-check against IFRS 18.55 for proper categorization.

items.question: Does the entity invest in financial assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of its other resources?
items.original_question: If the entity invests in financial assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of its other resources, does it classify related income and expenses on cash and cash equivalents in the operating category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity invest in financial assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of its other resources?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's financial statements, particularly its investments disclosed in the Statement of Financial Position and related notes. Look for financial assets held for returns that are managed independently, such as certain types of equity or debt investments. Cross-check with IFRS 18 for definitions of financial assets. Ensure you consider the intention and context of the investment.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify related income and expenses on cash and cash equivalents in the operating category?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the entity's Statement of Cash Flows and review how income and expenses related to cash and cash equivalents are presented. Ensure they are reported specifically under the operating category per IFRS 18.56(a). Look for common errors such as misclassification under investing or financing categories.

items.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?
items.original_question: If the entity provides financing to customers and does not meet the criteria in IFRS 18.56(a), does it classify related income and expenses from cash and cash equivalents that relate to providing financing to customers in the operating category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's business activities and contracts to identify if financing is provided to customers. Look for information in the financial statement notes or revenue-related disclosures under IFRS 18, including whether financing arrangements are explicit or embedded in transactions.

yes_case.question: Does the financing provided to customers fail to meet the criteria outlined in IFRS 18.56(a)?
yes_case.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.56(a) for the specific criteria that determine whether the financing arrangement impacts the transaction price. Criteria typically address the significance of the financing period (more than one year) and whether adjustments related to time value of money are required.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify related income and expenses from cash and cash equivalents that relate to providing financing to customers within the operating category?
yes_case.guidance: Ensure that related income or expenses linked to financing activities are correctly reported under the operating category in the Statement of Cash Flows, as required by IFRS. Verify this classification by examining the notes to financial statements and the detailed breakdown of cash flows.

items.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?
items.original_question: If the entity provides financing to customers and does not meet the criteria in IFRS 18.56(a), does it classify related income and expenses from cash and cash equivalents that do not relate to providing financing to customers based on an accounting policy choice between operating or investing category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's business operations and contracts with customers to determine if financing is provided. Consult documentation such as customer financing agreements, loan provisions, or third-party financing arrangements as outlined in IFRS 18. Ensure that financing is specifically related to customer transactions.

yes_case.question: Does the entity meet the criteria in IFRS 18.56(a)?
yes_case.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.56(a) for the specific criteria regarding financing arrangements. Ensure that these include the identification of a significant financing component and alignment with the obligation to account for the timing and value of payments. Pay particular attention to the terms and conditions of the payment schedules.

no_case.question: Are related income and expenses from cash and cash equivalents that do not relate to providing financing correctly classified based on the accounting policy choice between operating or investing categories?
no_case.guidance: Review the entity's accounting policy disclosure for classification of cash and cash equivalents. Confirm whether the policy choice is consistently applied and aligns with IFRS requirements for presentation in either the operating or investing category. Common errors include inconsistent classification or lack of policy disclosure.

items.question: Does the entity invest in other assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of its other resources?
items.original_question: If the entity invests in other assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of its other resources, does it classify related income and expenses on those assets in the operating category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity invest in other assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of its other resources?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity’s investment holdings as per the balance sheet and accompanying notes. Focus on assets like investments held at fair value, equity securities, or other income-generating financial instruments that operate separately from the entity’s core operations. Verify if the income and expenses are distinct and identifiable. Common pitfalls include overlooking assets commingled with operating resources.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify related income and expenses on those assets in the operating category within the Statement of Profit or Loss?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the Statement of Profit or Loss and related disclosures. Check whether identified income and expenses from such assets (e.g., interest, dividends, fair value adjustments) are categorized under 'Operating activities', rather than other categories like 'Investing' or 'Financing'. Ensure classification aligns with IFRS 18.58 requirements.

items.question: Does the entity have liabilities arising from transactions that involve only the raising of finance?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify income and expenses from the initial and subsequent measurement of liabilities arising from transactions that involve only the raising of finance in the financing category, except as set out in IFRS 18.63–66?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have liabilities arising from transactions that involve only the raising of finance?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the Statement of Financial Position and relevant notes on liabilities. Look specifically for borrowings, bonds payable, or other forms of debt that are created solely for financing purposes. Exclude any liabilities that arise from operating or investing transactions.

yes_case.question: Has the entity classified income and expenses from the initial and subsequent measurement of those financing liabilities in the financing category in the statement of profit or loss?
yes_case.guidance: Review the statement of profit or loss and its notes. Verify that income and expenses such as interest expense and fair value adjustments (if applicable) are classified in the financing category, as required by IFRS 18.60. Confirm that these items are not improperly classified under operating or investing categories.

yes_case.question: Does the classification comply with exceptions outlined in IFRS 18.63–66?
yes_case.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.63–66 to determine if any exceptions to the classification are applicable. This includes transactions involving specific hedging relationships or structured financing arrangements that might require a different treatment. Ensure the entity has appropriately applied the exceptions if relevant.

items.question: Did the entity engage in transactions involving the issue or extinguishment of liabilities to raise finance during the reporting period?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify incremental expenses directly attributable to the issue and extinguishment of liabilities arising from transactions that involve only the raising of finance in the financing category?

decision_tree.question: Did the entity engage in transactions involving the issue or extinguishment of liabilities to raise finance during the reporting period?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the Statement of Cash Flows and supporting documentation, such as contracts, transaction records, and notes to the financial statements. Look for evidence of liability-related transactions specifically aimed at raising finance, such as bond issuance, loan drawdowns, or repayments. Ensure these transactions pertain solely to finance-raising activities and not operating or investing activities.

yes_case.question: Were incremental expenses directly attributable to the issue or extinguishment of liabilities recognized by the entity?
yes_case.guidance: Examine accounting records, journal entries, and supporting invoices to determine if expenses like legal fees, underwriting fees, or commissions were incurred specifically for these financing transactions. Ensure they are identifiable and directly related.

yes_case.question: Are these incremental expenses classified correctly within the financing category on the Statement of Cash Flows?
yes_case.guidance: Verify the classification of these expenses in the Statement of Cash Flows. According to IFRS 18.60, such expenses must be presented within the financing activities section. Validate against IFRS guidelines to confirm compliance.

items.question: Does the entity have interest income or expenses arising from liabilities?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify interest income and expenses from liabilities arising from transactions that do not involve only the raising of finance in the financing category if identified for IFRS purposes?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have interest income or expenses arising from liabilities?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the entity's financial records, particularly interest-related transactions recorded in the Statement of Profit or Loss and OCI or the related Notes. Look for any liabilities where interest income or expense is recorded. Be aware of liabilities related to financing versus other transactions.

yes_case.question: Do the liabilities relate exclusively to the raising of finance?
yes_case.guidance: Review the nature of the liabilities in the Notes to the Financial Statements. Liabilities related to the raising of finance typically include bank loans, bonds, or other debt instruments. Exclude liabilities linked to operating or investing activities.

no_case.question: Does the entity correctly classify the interest income and expenses from these liabilities in the financing category for IFRS purposes?
no_case.guidance: Verify the classification of interest income and expenses in the Statement of Cash Flows and other financial statements. Ensure compliance with IFRS 18.61, which requires classification in the financing category if not exclusively related to financing activities.

items.question: Does the entity have liabilities arising from transactions that do not involve only the raising of finance?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify income and expenses arising from changes in interest rates on liabilities arising from transactions that do not involve only the raising of finance in the financing category if identified for IFRS purposes?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have liabilities arising from transactions that do not involve only the raising of finance?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's liabilities in the statement of financial position. Identify transactions that involve liabilities arising from operations, such as lease liabilities, financial instruments, or deferred income. Ensure these liabilities are not solely related to borrowing or other financing activities. Common pitfalls include misclassifying liabilities—compare with the nature of the transactions in the underlying contracts and IFRS 18 guidance.

yes_case.question: Do changes in interest rates impact the income and expenses related to these liabilities?
yes_case.guidance: Analyze the income and expense items reported in the profit and loss statement. Determine whether interest rate fluctuations have caused significant changes to income and expenses for these liabilities. Check supporting documents like contract terms and calculation schedules.

yes_case.question: Are these income and expenses classified under the financing category in the financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the entity's presentation in the statement of profit or loss. Verify whether these income and expenses are included under the financing category. Consult IFRS 18.61 for specific categorization rules. Avoid errors by reviewing the notes to financial statements and classification explanations.

items.question: Is the entity using a hedging instrument designated under IFRS 9 for risk management purposes?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on a hedging instrument designated under IFRS 9 in the same category as the income and expenses affected by the risks managed?

decision_tree.question: Is the entity using a hedging instrument designated under IFRS 9 for risk management purposes?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the financial statements and accounting policies to determine if the entity has designated any financial instruments as hedging instruments under IFRS 9. Review sections outlining financial instruments and hedging practices. Common pitfalls include misclassification or omitting hedging designations in disclosures.

yes_case.question: Are the gains and losses on the hedging instrument classified in the same category as the income and expenses affected by the risks managed?
yes_case.guidance: Locate the area of the financial statements where gains and losses on hedging instruments are disclosed. Verify the classification matches the category of income and expenses affected by the hedged risk. Pay attention to accompanying notes or sections detailing hedge accounting treatment under IFRS 9.

items.question: Does the entity use hedging instruments designated under IFRS 9?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on a hedging instrument designated under IFRS 9 in the operating category if required to avoid grossing up?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity use hedging instruments designated under IFRS 9?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's financial statements and note disclosures, specifically under IFRS 9. Check if hedging relationships are formally designated and documented according to IFRS 9 requirements. Common pitfalls: Ensure that hedge accounting is properly applied and documented.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify gains and losses from hedging instruments in the operating category to avoid grossing up?
yes_case.guidance: Verify that the gains and losses on hedging instruments are presented in the operating category only if this classification is required to maintain coherency and avoid grossing up within financial categories. Review the income statement and the notes disclosures for classification practices.

items.question: Does the entity have a designated hedging relationship involving a hedging instrument?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on an undesignated component of a designated hedging instrument in the same category as the designated component?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have a designated hedging relationship involving a hedging instrument?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's financial statements, specifically the notes on hedge accounting under IFRS 9. Look for disclosures regarding designated hedging relationships that involve hedging instruments. Ensure these are formally documented in line with hedge accounting requirements under IFRS 9 Section 6.

yes_case.question: Does the hedging instrument have an undesignated component?
yes_case.guidance: Identify if the hedging instrument has any portion that is not designated within the hedge relationship. This information can typically be found in hedge accounting documentation or financial statement disclosures concerning risk management practices.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on the undesignated component of the hedging instrument in the same category as the designated component?
yes_case.guidance: Verify the presentation of gains and losses on both the designated and undesignated components by reviewing the notes on hedge accounting. Specifically check whether gains and losses from the undesignated components follow the same classification criteria as the designated part per IFRS 9 Section 6.4.

items.question: Does the entity apply hedge accounting under IFRS 9?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify ineffective portions of a gain or loss in the same category as the effective portions?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity apply hedge accounting under IFRS 9?
decision_tree.guidance: Refer to the entity's accounting policies and financial statements. Check whether the entity has designated hedging relationships and applies hedge accounting as per IFRS 9. If there are no hedging relationships or hedge accounting is not applied, this checklist is irrelevant.

yes_case.question: Does the entity's hedge involve gains or losses that have both effective and ineffective portions?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the documentation for each designated hedge. Obtain the hedge effectiveness testing results (e.g., prospective and retrospective tests) to identify ineffective portions. Ineffective portions are reported separately from effective portions in financial statements.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify ineffective portions of a gain or loss in the same category as the effective portions in the financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Review the financial statement presentation, particularly under the Statement of Comprehensive Income or the Statement of Profit and Loss. Ensure that the ineffective portions are presented consistently with the effective portions, as required by IFRS 9.B71 guidance.

items.question: Does the entity hold derivatives not designated as hedges under IFRS 9?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on a derivative not designated as a hedge under IFRS 9 in the same category as the income and expenses affected by the risks managed?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity hold derivatives not designated as hedges under IFRS 9?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity’s financial instruments disclosures in the notes to the financial statements. Look specifically for derivatives and confirm they are not designated as hedging instruments per IFRS 9 requirements. Common pitfalls include misclassification of derivatives or incomplete disclosure in the financial statements.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on the derivative in the same category as the income and expenses affected by the risks managed?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the statement of profit or loss and related disclosures. Verify that gains and losses on these derivatives are presented in the same income or expense category as the items impacted by the risks the derivatives are meant to manage. Common pitfalls include misalignment between derivative impact and related income/expenses or lack of clear disclosure.

items.question: Does the entity hold derivatives that are not designated as hedges according to IFRS 9?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on a derivative not designated as a hedge under IFRS 9 in the operating category if required to avoid grossing up or undue cost or effort?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity hold derivatives that are not designated as hedges according to IFRS 9?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the financial statements, particularly the notes to derivative financial instruments. Check whether any derivatives held do not meet the criteria for hedge accounting under IFRS 9. Common pitfalls include overlooking embedded derivatives or incorrectly classified hedging relationships.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify gains and losses from these derivatives in the operating category in its Statement of Profit or Loss?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the Statement of Profit or Loss and related notes. Verify that gains and losses from derivatives not designated as hedges are included in the operating category, consistent with IFRS 18.B72. Ensure classification avoids grossing up and undue cost or effort.

no_case.question: Has the entity provided justification for classifying gains and losses outside the operating category, with evidence of avoiding undue cost or effort?
no_case.guidance: Look for disclosures or explanations in the financial statement notes indicating a valid reason (e.g., avoiding undue cost or effort) for alternative classification. Ensure justification is clearly supported and reasonable based on materiality thresholds.

items.question: Does the entity engage in transactions involving derivatives?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on a derivative not used to manage identified risks in the financing category if it relates to raising finance, or in the operating category if the entity provides financing to customers as a main business activity?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity engage in transactions involving derivatives?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity’s financial statements and accounting policies to identify if derivatives are reported. Derivatives include contracts such as interest rate swaps, foreign exchange contracts, and commodity futures. Check if these are disclosed in the notes, typically under financial instruments or risk management sections.

yes_case.question: Is the derivative used to manage identified risks related to the entity’s financing activities?
yes_case.guidance: Determine the purpose of the derivative by reviewing the accounting policy note and relevant disclosures. If the derivative is explicitly designated for managing risks such as interest rate, foreign exchange, or credit risks associated with financing activities, it likely meets this condition.

yes_case.question: Has the entity classified gains and losses from such derivatives correctly under the financing category?
yes_case.guidance: Review the Statement of Profit or Loss and Other Comprehensive Income (P&L) for classification. Gains and losses on derivatives related to financing should appear under the financing category, often part of finance costs or income. Cross-check disclosures for consistency.

no_case.question: Does the derivative relate to financing provided to customers as part of the entity’s main business activity?
no_case.guidance: Check if the entity operates in a sector (e.g., banking, leasing) where providing financing to customers is a primary business activity. If the derivative is associated with customer financing, gains and losses should be classified under the operating category in the Statement of Profit or Loss. Validate this through segment disclosures or specific business activities described in the notes.

yes_case.question: Has the entity classified gains and losses from such derivatives correctly under the operating category?
yes_case.guidance: Review the P&L to determine if gains and losses from customer financing-related derivatives are presented under operating activities. Ensure this is consistent with the entity’s disclosures and accounting policies.

items.question: Does the entity hold derivatives?
items.original_question: Does the entity classify gains and losses on a derivative not used to manage identified risks in the operating category if the conditions in IFRS 18.B73(a) are not met?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity hold derivatives?
decision_tree.guidance: Check the entity's financial statements, particularly under 'Financial Instruments' or 'Derivatives', and review disclosures related to investments and risk management strategies. Look for references to derivatives in the notes to the accounts.

yes_case.question: Are these derivatives used to manage identified risks?
yes_case.guidance: Review the entity's risk management disclosure and policies. Check IFRS 18.B73(a) for the specific conditions that classify derivatives as risk-management tools, such as being designated in a hedging relationship or supported by a documented risk management objective.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify gains and losses from these derivatives in the operating category?
yes_case.guidance: Check the Statement of Profit or Loss and the related notes. Verify where gains and losses from derivatives are presented. Ensure alignment with the operating category only if the derivative meets the criteria for risk management purposes under IFRS 18.B73(a).

no_case.question: Does the entity classify gains and losses from these derivatives in the operating category contrary to IFRS 18.B73?
no_case.guidance: Review the Statement of Profit or Loss for classification. Confirm that derivatives not used for identified risks should not be categorized under the operating category according to IFRS 18.B73.

items.question: Does the entity issue investment contracts with participation features?
items.original_question: Does the entity exclude from the financing category and classify in the operating category income and expenses from issued investment contracts with participation features recognised under IFRS 9?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity issue investment contracts with participation features?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's financial statements and disclosures, particularly under Notes related to financial instruments. Look for investment contracts with participation features identified under IFRS 9. Pay special attention to contracts classified as financial liabilities or that share risks and returns with contract holders.

yes_case.question: Are the income and expenses from these investment contracts classified under the operating category in the Statement of Cash Flows?
yes_case.guidance: Check the Statement of Cash Flows under the operating category. Income and expenses from issued investment contracts with participation features should be excluded from the financing category and placed in the operating category as per IFRS 18.64.

items.question: Does the entity have insurance finance income and expenses recognized under IFRS 17?
items.original_question: Does the entity exclude from the financing category and classify in the operating category insurance finance income and expenses recognised under IFRS 17?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have insurance finance income and expenses recognized under IFRS 17?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the financial statements for any items classified as insurance finance income and expenses. These are typically disclosed under IFRS 17 in relation to insurance contracts. Check the notes to the financial statements for specific references to IFRS 17 and for amounts categorized as insurance finance income and expenses.

yes_case.question: Has the entity classified insurance finance income and expenses in the operating category rather than the financing category, as required by IFRS 18.64?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the Statement of Cash Flows and related disclosures. Verify that insurance finance income and expenses are explicitly placed in the operating category. If they appear in the financing category, this would contravene IFRS 18.64. Pay attention to the detailed line items and ensure compliance with the standard.

items.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's operations, specifically contracts and transactions with customers. Check for the existence of financing arrangements in revenue contracts. This can be found in the entity's revenue contracts and supporting notes to the financial statements under IFRS 18 disclosures.

yes_case.question: Does the entity have liabilities that arise solely from transactions involving the raising of finance to provide customer financing?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the Statement of Financial Position and related notes for liabilities that are designated exclusively for financing customer arrangements (e.g., bank loans or bonds explicitly raised to fund customer finance). Cross-check documentation for intended use of such liabilities.

yes_case.question: Are the income and expenses from these liabilities correctly classified in the operating category within the financial statements?
yes_case.guidance: Inspect the income and expense accounts in the Statement of Profit or Loss for classification of financing-related items tied to customer financing. Ensure that these are recorded in the operating section and not incorrectly presented elsewhere, such as in financing activities or investing activities.

items.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers as part of its business activities?
items.original_question: If the entity provides financing to customers, does it classify income and expenses from liabilities that arise from transactions involving only the raising of finance based on an accounting policy choice when those liabilities do not relate to providing financing?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers as part of its business activities?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the nature of the entity's operations, contracts, and revenue streams to determine if financing is offered to customers (e.g., loans, extended payment terms). Check sales contracts and revenue-related disclosures for financing components.

yes_case.question: Do liabilities arise from transactions involving only the raising of finance (and not from financing provided to customers)?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the entity's balance sheet and related notes. Determine whether there are liabilities that are strictly related to the raising of finance, such as borrowings or bonds, and ensure they are not linked to customer financing activities.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify income and expenses from these liabilities based on an appropriate accounting policy choice?
yes_case.guidance: Verify that the financial statements describe the accounting policy applied to classify income and expenses from such liabilities clearly and consistently. Confirm compliance with IFRS 18.65(a). Review journal entries and policy documentation to ensure transactions align with the chosen policy.

items.question: Does the entity have liabilities related to providing financing to customers?
items.original_question: If the entity cannot distinguish between liabilities related and not related to providing financing to customers, does it classify all related income and expenses in the operating category?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity have liabilities related to providing financing to customers?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's balance sheet and note disclosures to identify liabilities associated with financing to customers. Common examples include customer deposits, short-term loans, or credit arrangements explicitly tied to customer agreements.

yes_case.question: Can the entity distinguish between liabilities related to providing financing to customers and liabilities that are not related to such financing?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the entity's accounting records and disclosures for clear classifications of liabilities. Verify the entity's ability to separate financing-related liabilities from non-financing-related liabilities in their financial systems and reporting documentation.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify income and expenses related to financing liabilities in accordance with IFRS classification guidance (e.g., within operating, investing, or financing categories)?
yes_case.guidance: Refer to IFRS 18.65(a) for guidance on the appropriate classification of income and expenses. Verify that financing-related items are correctly allocated to the required category on the Statement of Profit or Loss.

no_case.question: Does the entity classify all income and expenses related to the indistinguishable liabilities in the operating category?
no_case.guidance: Review the Statement of Profit or Loss. Check whether all associated income and expenses are aggregated under the operating category when they cannot be distinguished. Validate the entity's rationale and compliance with IFRS 18.65(a).

decision_tree.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?
decision_tree.guidance: Review contracts, terms of sales, and customer agreements. Financing typically includes situations where the entity allows deferred payment terms or charges interest on outstanding balances. Check for accounts receivable, loan agreements, or other financing arrangements.

yes_case.question: Do the income and expenses from liabilities arise solely from transactions involving the raising of finance?
yes_case.guidance: Identify the nature of liabilities in the entity's financial statements. Refer to IFRS 18.61 for guidance on what constitutes liabilities arising solely from the raising of finance. Common pitfalls include misclassifying liabilities associated with mixed transactions, such as service fees combined with financing elements.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify such income and expenses in the financing category as specified in IFRS 18.65(b)?
yes_case.guidance: Review the Statement of Financial Performance and the accounting policies note. Ensure that income and expenses from these liabilities are appropriately classified under 'financing'. Verify compliance with IFRS 18.65(b). Watch for errors such as misclassification under operating or investing categories.

items.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?

decision_tree.question: Does the entity provide financing to customers?
decision_tree.guidance: Review the entity's agreements, contracts, or business activities to identify if financing services are offered to customers beyond typical payment terms. Check transaction details in note disclosures and customer agreements.

yes_case.question: Do the liabilities that arise from such financing transactions involve activities beyond solely the raising of finance?
yes_case.guidance: Analyze the nature of these liabilities based on IFRS 18.61 and related disclosures. Determine if their purpose includes activities connected to operations (e.g., customer-related financing) rather than being limited to pure financing activities.

yes_case.question: Does the entity classify income and expenses from these liabilities in the operating category when it is not specified otherwise in IFRS 18.61?
yes_case.guidance: Examine the presentation in the financial statements. Ensure that income and expenses linked to these liabilities are correctly reported in the operating category, as guided by IFRS 18.65(b). Verify compliance with presentation requirements and consider consistency in classification.

items.question: Does the entity have tax expense or tax income reported in the statement of profit or loss?
